channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Shopping, Skating, and Swimming – Is This Even Work? Perl developer in Dubai
item.description: Our client is a financial company whose growth over the last twenty years has been nothing short of impressive. They started with the idea that online trading should be available to all, and from there, they’ve built a company with multiple locations worldwide. If you want to be part of a business that is thriving, this may be the perfect opportunity for you.

item.title: Business Casual has a Whole New Meaning. Perl role in South Germany
item.description: Online shopping, socializing, working—it’s a digital world now, which is perfect for our client. As an international IT company managing millions of domains for retail and corporate customers in nearly every country in the world, they’re busier than ever—and they need a few senior Perl developers to help them continue to thrive.

item.title: If it was Good Enough for Mozart - Perl role in Vienna
item.description: As one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries, they know all about finding the best products at a price that would make Mozart shout, “Wunderbar!” They want to find a Perl programmer who thrives on delivering quality content, well-executed user information that’s easy to understand, and is as committed to transparency and excellence as they are.

item.title: Distraction-free Workplace - Escape Standups and Scrum - Perl Developer West London
item.description: Client is a small development team where everyone is expected to pull their own weight. No daily standups, no planning poker, just you and your work, aided by some of the most experienced technical colleagues in London. You’ll be encouraged to make sensible use of Modern Perl tooling and grow your personal experience of best development practices under excellent technical leadership.

item.title: Paging Dr. Perl! Perl Role in Cambridge, UK
item.description: This organization is one of the world’s leading developers of medical diagnostic technologies and clinical software. They believe in security, wellness, and the importance of driving innovation to deliver patient benefit. You won’t be in a white coat, but it’s better than that—your work will be used by the NHS, research labs, and healthcare providers worldwide.

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2021
item.description: It will be in Leipzig on March 24-26 2021. CFP is open.

item.title: Berlin Perl Mongers
item.description: Wednesday, January 6, 2021; 7:00 PM GMT+1

item.title: Toronto Perl Mongers Online Meeting
item.description: Thursday, December 24, 2020; 7:00 PM EST

item.title: Starship Mongers
item.description: Wednesday, December 9, 2020; 5:30 PM EST

item.title: Silicon Valley Perl - Quantum::Superpositions, 2021 election
item.description: Thursday, December 3, 2020, 6:30 PM PST

item.title: COVID 19 charts by DungeonTiger
item.description: Screencast showing a GitHub pages project where the content is re-generated twice a day with a scheduled GitHub Actions job.

item.title: CPAN Digger - CPAN Dashboard - CPAN Rocks
item.description: Screencast showing you around the 3 projects. CPAN Digger by Gabor Szabo, CPAN Dashboard by Dave Cross, both written in Perl and hosted on GitHub pages. CPAN Rocks by James Raspass, written in Raku and hosted on GitLab.

item.title: GitLab CI for Perl projects
item.description: List of Perl projects hosted on GitLab that already have GitLab CI enabled. Some projects to learn from.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Use Perl::Tidy module in your application
item.description: Simple example showing how to use Perl::Tidy as a module and not as a command line tool, embedded in your application.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 088
item.description: Walt used very elegantly state variables to solve the Spiral Matrix task.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 088
item.description: Simon presenting step-by-step solution to the Spiral Matrix is interesting.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 088
item.description: The best of the blog is the discussion of the Spiral Matrix solution. Must Read.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 88: Spiral Product
item.description: Roger blog is not limited to Perl solution. You will find comparative solutions in other languages too.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 088
item.description: Lubos doing Perl and Python side by side is really interesting. It makes it easy to read.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 88: Array of Products and Spiral Matrices
item.description: Laurent doing Raku first then porting the same to Perl is really cool. His contributions in Perl and Raku are equally great.

item.title: PWC088 - Spiral Matrix
item.description: Flavio style of question and answer in the blog make me think again and again.

item.title: PWC088 - Array of Product
item.description: Flavio continued the weekly challenge journey with so much fun.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challege: 088
item.description: I loved the blogging style followed by Jaldhar. Keeping track of the code while discussing the solution.

item.title: Solving Perl Weekly Challenge 088 -- Array of Prodict vs Spiral Matrix
item.description: Kang-min use of map for keeping track of direction is really nice. The blog showing the real power of Raku.

item.title: The Product of the Absence – Spiralize the Day Away
item.description: Colin, our in-house, Perl Reviewer, came up with an interesting blog showing the power of Perl and Raku.

item.title: CY's Take on PWC#088
item.description: Cheok-Yin blog is always fun to read. Plenty to absorb the meat of the solution.

item.title: Arrayed Spiral with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne use of mapping analogy for the Spiral Matrix is coolest way. We are blessed you have both Perl and Raku version this week.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 088
item.description: Adam keeps the discussion short and sweet.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 88, Part 2
item.description: Abigail has been a great supporter and his blog contribution is the talk of the town.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 88, Part 1
item.description: The blog goes into finer details of the task in terms of Perl, C and Node.js.

item.title: Meet The Champion - Andrew Shitov
item.description: Finally we managed to get the interview done. Worth the wait imho.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 088
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week contributions by Team PWC, dealing with the "Array of Products" and "Spiral Matrix" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 089
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "GCD Sum" and "Magical Matrix". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Maintaining the Perl 5 Core (Dave Mitchell): Grant Report for October 2020
CPAN Digger explained
item.description: Gabor sharing the internals of CPAN Digger.

item.title: Variables, loops, and redirections
item.description: Interesting discussion about the very basics variables, loops and redirections.

item.title: Peek in containers
item.description: Take a peek in containers with this short blog.

item.title: Put a file in a Kubernetes Pod
item.description: Flavio another gem of a blog showing how to put a file in a Kubernetes pod.

item.title: A few tips for Perl on Docker and Kubernetes
item.description: A very handy introduction for anyone trying to get their hand dirty.

item.title: Blogs
item.description: Number of posts last week: BPO: 5; DevTo: 5; Perl.com: 0; PerlAcademy: 2; PerlHacks: 0; PerlMaven: 4; Reddit: 17; TPF: 1;

item.title: CPAN uploads
item.description: Last week there were a total of 171 uploads to CPAN of 137 distinct distributions by 80 different authors. Number of distributions with link to VCS: 94. Number of distros with CI: 44. Number of distros with bugtracker: 66.

item.title: The Pearls of Perl - The top 10 Perl tools for every developer
item.description: From A (Ack) to Z (Dist-Zilla), check out the 10 Perl tools that should be in every developer’s toolbox. Or Download our “Pearls of Perl” build to get a version of Perl 5.28 with all the tools listed in this post so you can test them out for yourself!

item.title: #488 - Advent Calendar 2020
item.description:
Hi there

It is time to get ready for Advent Calendar 2020. Last year Advent Calendar was the best so far as there was a flood of Advent Calendars. Most notably was Perl and Raku. The best of all was the one by Andrew Shitov, where we were introduced to a new language each day.

So what do I expect in the COVID-19 year 2020?

Well, first of all, I would like to have Advent Calendar for Dancer2 back. I missed it dearly last year. Dancer2 is very close to my heart. I had the honour to be part of Advent Calendar in the past once. Whoever is responsible this year, please don't let us down this time.

Have you contributed to Perl/Raku Advent Calendar?

If not then why not give it a try. For me it is like getting your name in the history book forever. Last year, I contributed to Raku Advent Calendar for the first time. Before that, I even had the pleasure to be part of Perl Advent Calendar. The best part of any Advent Calendar is the surprise element. Every day brings a new fun subject to explore.

My pet project The Weekly Challenge also created the first Advent Calendar last year. I haven't had the time to plan this year Advent Calendar. Having said, I am going to do my best not to disappoint fan of The Weekly Challenge.

Is that all for for us in the month of December?

Well, no. There is another fun challenge for those who enjoy contributing opensource codebase and it is called 24 Pull Requests. I haven't had good time contributing in the year 2019 for many reasons as compare to my past records. Having said, I would be taking part again this year and complete the challenge without fail.

We would love to know your plan with regard to Advent Calendar or 24 Pull Request. Please do share your story with us. Last but not the least, please do take care of yourself and your family. Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
